item.title: Trump Holds Briefing On Opioid Crisis Amid Pleas To Declare National Emergency
item.description: August 8, 2017 - President Trump received a briefing on the opioid crisis while vacationing in New Jersey. It comes as his commission on the issue is urging him to declare the problem a national emergency.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 8, 2017 - President Trump received a briefing on the opioid crisis while vacationing in New Jersey. It comes as his commission on the issue is urging him to declare the problem a national emergency. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/08/542286057/trump-holds-briefing-on-opioid-crisis-amid-pleas-to-declare-national-emergency

item.title: First Responders Spending More On Overdose Reversal Drug
item.description: August 8, 2017 - With price hikes and rising demand, the drug naloxone, which can reverse an opioid overdose, is taking up an ever-larger share of emergency department budgets.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 8, 2017 - With price hikes and rising demand, the drug naloxone, which can reverse an opioid overdose, is taking up an ever-larger share of emergency department budgets. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/08/541626627/first-responders-spending-more-on-overdose-reversal-drug

item.title: Big Employers Say They Will Continue To Offer Health Plans To Their Workers
item.description: August 8, 2017 - Three years ago, only about a quarter of the nation's large employers were "very confident" they would offer health insurance to their workers in 10 years. That number has now risen to 65 percent.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 8, 2017 - Three years ago, only about a quarter of the nation's large employers were "very confident" they would offer health insurance to their workers in 10 years. That number has now risen to 65 percent. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/08/542236997/big-employers-say-theyll-continue-to-offer-health-plans-to-their-workers

item.title: Gnawing Questions: Is Sugar From Fruit The Same As Sugar From Candy?
item.description:
August 8, 2017 - Stories about the harms of sugar have consumers wondering whether they should put the apple back on the shelf.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/08/08/540923229/gnawing-questions-is-sugar-from-fruit-the-same-as-sugar-from-candy
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 8, 2017 - Stories about the harms of sugar have consumers wondering whether they should put the apple back on the shelf. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/08/08/540923229/gnawing-questions-is-sugar-from-fruit-the-same-as-sugar-from-candy

item.title: When People With Autism Encounter Police
item.description:
August 8, 2017 - Missed social cues are awkward. But what happens when poor communication is a matter of life and death?
- http://the1a.org/shows/2017-08-08/when-people-with-autism-encounter-police
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 8, 2017 - Missed social cues are awkward. But what happens when poor communication is a matter of life and death? http://the1a.org/shows/2017-08-08/when-people-with-autism-encounter-police

item.title: A Chip That Reprograms Cells Helps Healing, At Least In Mice
item.description: August 8, 2017 - This device shoots new genetic code into cells to make them change their purpose. Researchers say the chip could someday be used to treat injuries in humans. But they've got a long, long way to go.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 8, 2017 - This device shoots new genetic code into cells to make them change their purpose. Researchers say the chip could someday be used to treat injuries in humans. But they've got a long, long way to go. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/08/542057520/a-chip-that-reprograms-cells-helps-healing-at-least-in-mice

item.title: Nashville Mayor Mourns Son's Overdose Death, Urges Families To Talk About Addiction
item.description: August 8, 2017 - "Max is not going to text me back. I'm not going to hear his voice again," Mayor Megan Barry said of her only child. The 22-year-old died last month of an apparent overdose near Denver.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 8, 2017 - "Max is not going to text me back. I'm not going to hear his voice again," Mayor Megan Barry said of her only child. The 22-year-old died last month of an apparent overdose near Denver. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/08/542116681/nashville-mayor-mourning-sons-overdose-death-aims-to-save-other-children

item.title: How Smartphones Are Making Kids Unhappy
item.description: August 7, 2017 - Psychologist Jean Twenge has observed dramatic shifts in behavior among children who go through adolescence with smartphones. They're spending less time with friends and reporting greater anxiety.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 7, 2017 - Psychologist Jean Twenge has observed dramatic shifts in behavior among children who go through adolescence with smartphones. They're spending less time with friends and reporting greater anxiety. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/07/542016165/how-smartphones-are-making-kids-unhappy

item.title: Can Buddhist Practices Help Us Overcome The Biological Pull Of Dissatisfaction?
item.description: August 7, 2017 - Science journalist and author Robert Wright says that Buddhist enlightenment might help counteract our natural tendency towards unhappiness. His new book is Why Buddhism is True.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 7, 2017 - Science journalist and author Robert Wright says that Buddhist enlightenment might help counteract our natural tendency towards unhappiness. His new book is Why Buddhism is True. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/07/541610511/can-buddhist-practices-help-us-overcome-the-biological-pull-of-dissatisfaction

item.title: Experimenting With Drugs While Terminally Ill
item.description:
August 7, 2017 - States and federal lawmakers want patients to be able to request access to treatments that haven't been approved for wider use.
- http://the1a.org/shows/2017-08-07/experimenting-with-drugs-while-terminally-ill
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 7, 2017 - States and federal lawmakers want patients to be able to request access to treatments that haven't been approved for wider use. http://the1a.org/shows/2017-08-07/experimenting-with-drugs-while-terminally-ill

item.title: Flattening The 'Mummy Tummy' With 1 Exercise, 10 Minutes A Day
item.description: August 7, 2017 - The technical term is diastasis recti and it affects many new moms. The growing fetus pushes apart the abdominal muscles and the separation often stays open. But science suggests this fix can work.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 7, 2017 - The technical term is diastasis recti and it affects many new moms. The growing fetus pushes apart the abdominal muscles and the separation often stays open. But science suggests this fix can work. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/07/541204499/flattening-the-mummy-tummy-with-1-exercise-10-minutes-a-day

item.title: Acid Attacks On The Rise In The U.K.
item.description:
August 6, 2017 - Corrosive substances are increasingly used as weapons in the U.K., especially in London, which had more than 450 attacks in 2016.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/08/06/541209398/acid-attacks-on-the-rise-in-the-u-k
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Your ZIP Code Might Be As Important To Health As Your Genetic Code
item.description: August 4, 2017 - Health care forms increasingly ask about more than just medical history. That's because doctors are beginning to understand that patients' stress, and how and where they live, influence health, too.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 4, 2017 - Health care forms increasingly ask about more than just medical history. That's because doctors are beginning to understand that patients' stress, and how and where they live, influence health, too. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/04/539757759/your-zip-code-can-be-as-important-to-health-as-your-genetic-code

item.title: South Texas Fights Tuberculosis One Blood Test At A Time
item.description: August 4, 2017 - Texas has one of the highest rates of TB among U.S. states. A sweeping effort is underway, largely funded by Medicaid, to diagnose and treat people who don't know they harbor the lung infection.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 4, 2017 - Texas has one of the highest rates of TB among U.S. states. A sweeping effort is underway, largely funded by Medicaid, to diagnose and treat people who don't know they harbor the lung infection. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/04/539800393/south-texas-fights-tuberculosis-one-blood-test-at-a-time

item.title: Scientists Aim For Better, Cheaper Tests For Alzheimer's
item.description: August 4, 2017 - The goal is to find accurate, painless tests that can help doctors diagnose Alzheimer's early and track the progression of the illness and any response to treatment. A few tests seem promising.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 4, 2017 - The goal is to find accurate, painless tests that can help doctors diagnose Alzheimer's early and track the progression of the illness and any response to treatment. A few tests seem promising. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/04/541393576/scientists-aim-for-better-cheaper-tests-for-alzheimers
